To Clean Engine Cylinder Heads
[Instructions B:]

2. Scrape off head gasket material with a plastic scraper. (Time: 10 minute(s)) (Tools: Scraper)
3. Soak the cylinder head in a tub with liquid parts cleaner and scrub it with a rag. (Time: 20 minute(s)) (Tools: Bucket, Cloth)
4. Submerge the cylinder head in a tub of warm water and let it sit for a few minutes. (Time: 5 minute(s)) (Tools: Bucket)
5. Remove the cylinder head from the water and dry it with a clean rag. (Time: 8 minute(s)) (Tools: Bucket, Cloth)
6. Use compressed air to blow out any remaining water from hard-to-reach places. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Compressor)

3. Insert the new pedals into the pedal holes. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)
4. Tighten the new pedals into place with the wrench. (Time: 6 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)

4. Apply anti-seize lubricant on the metal contact edges and on the back of the new brake pads. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Sponge)
5. Insert the new brake pads in the same position. (Time: 6 minute(s)) (Tools: Pliers)

To Remove Lug Nuts and Tires
[Instructions A:]
1. Loosen the lug nuts by turning them a quarter turn counterclockwise with a tire iron or wrench. (Time: 5 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)
2. Jack up the car so the tire is no longer touching the ground. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Jack)
3. Unscrew the lug nuts the rest of the way with the tire iron or wrench. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)
4. Remove the lug nuts. (Time: 1 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
5. Pull the tire toward you to remove it. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: None)

To Fix Brakes on a Bike
[Instructions B:]
1. Remove the nuts and washers from the old brake pads. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench, Screwdriver)
2. Pull the old brake pads free from the calipers. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Screwdriver)
3. Put the new brake pads in the calipers, aligning them with the tires. (Time: 3 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)
4. Replace the nuts and washers. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)

Since we have all the required tools for both tasks, we can start analyzing the steps.

Task A:
1. Disconnect the car battery by loosening the nut holding the ground cable on the negative terminal. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)
2. Remove the trim separating the headlight assembly from the engine bay. (Time: 6 minute(s)) (Tools: Screwdriver)
3. Remove the headlight and wire pigtail from the headlight bracket or holder. (Time: 5 minute(s)) (Tools: Screwdriver)
4. Disconnect the wires leading into the headlight and pull the bulb from the bulb housing. (Time: 8 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
5. Remove any debris from the bulb housing. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Cloth)
6. Slide the new bulb gently into the bulb housing. (Time: 1 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
7. Connect the wiring pigtail to the back of the bulb assembly. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
8. Put the bulb assembly back into the headlight housing. (Time: 3 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
9. Reinstall the trim pieces. (Time: 6 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
10. Reconnect the battery. (Time: 3 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)

Task B:
1. Remove small parts like the camshafts and intake valves from the cylinder head. (Time: 15 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench, Screwdriver)
2. Scrape off head gasket material with a plastic scraper. (Time: 10 minute(s)) (Tools: Scraper)
3. Soak the cylinder head in a tub with liquid parts cleaner and scrub it with a rag. (Time: 20 minute(s)) (Tools: Bucket, Cloth)
4. Submerge the cylinder head in a tub of warm water and let it sit for a few minutes. (Time: 5 minute(s)) (Tools: Bucket)
5. Remove the cylinder head from the water and dry it with a clean rag. (Time: 8 minute(s)) (Tools: Bucket, Cloth)
6. Use compressed air to blow out any remaining water from hard-to-reach places. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Compressor)

Task A:
1. Clean the area on the car where the decal will be applied with a soft cloth and mild cleaner. (Time: 5 minute(s)) (Tools: Cloth)
2. Hold the decal up to the car, center it, and mark the corners with masking tape. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Cloth)
3. Peel off the back of the decal and place it on the car, pressing the corner firmly onto the vehicle. (Time: 1 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
4. Use a straight-edged tool to press the rest of the decal down. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Credit card)
5. Remove the transfer tape from the front of the decal after 30 minutes. (Time: 30 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
6. Use a credit card to remove any bubbles from the decal. (Time: 3 minute(s)) (Tools: Credit card)

Task B:
1. Heat the decal with a hairdryer or heat gun until the edges fray. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Dryer)
2. Hold a credit card or library card parallel to the window and slide it under one corner of the decal. (Time: 0.5 minute(s)) (Tools: Credit card)
3. Carefully scrape off the decal using the card. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Credit card)
4. Chip away at any remaining residue with the card. (Time: 3 minute(s)) (Tools: Credit card)
5. Use glass cleaner to remove any remaining residue. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Cloth)

3. Slide a plastic wedge or a long piece of floss behind the badge to remove it. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Dryer, Plastic wedge)
4. Remove any residue from the glue using adhesive remover. (Time: 6 minute(s)) (Tools: Cloth)

To Fix Brakes on a Bike
[Instructions A:]

2. Pull the old brake pads free from the calipers. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Screwdriver)
3. Put the new brake pads in the calipers, aligning them with the tires. (Time: 3 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)
4. Replace the nuts and washers. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)

To Replace Ball Joints

3. Slide the new joint into place. (Time: 5 minute(s)) (Tools: Wrench)
4. Pump the new joint full of grease. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Grease gun, Wrench)

To Remove Vinyl Decals from a Car Window
[Instructions A:]
1. Heat the decal with a hairdryer or heat gun until the edges fray. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Dryer)
2. Hold a credit card or library card parallel to the window and slide it under one corner of the decal. (Time: 0.5 minute(s)) (Tools: Credit card)
3. Carefully scrape off the decal using the card. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Credit card)
4. Chip away at any remaining residue with the card. (Time: 3 minute(s)) (Tools: Credit card)
5. Use glass cleaner to remove any remaining residue. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Cloth)

To Clean Leather Interior
[Instructions B:]
1. Wipe down the leather interior with a damp cloth. (Time: 5 minute(s)) (Tools: Cloth)
2. Vacuum up dirt using a soft-bristled brush attachment. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Vacuum cleaner, Soft brush)
3. Use a leather cleaner and gently scrub the interior. (Time: 8 minute(s)) (Tools: Stiff brush)
4. Wipe down the interior with a clean, damp cloth to remove any soap residue. (Time: 5 minute(s)) (Tools: Cloth)
5. Dry the interior with a clean, dry cloth. (Time: 6 minute(s)) (Tools: Cloth)

3. Apply the rubbing compound to the car's surface using the orbital polisher. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Polisher)
4. Rub the compound into the car's surface until it's invisible. (Time: 8 minute(s)) (Tools: Cloth)

How To Remove Egg Stains from Car Paint_:
To determine the optimal plan, let's analyze the tools required for each task and their availability.

Task A requires the following tools:
- Soft brush (1)
- Microfiber cloth (1)
- Sponge (1)
- Paintbrush (1)

Task B requires the following tools:
- Hose (1)
- Spray bottle (1)

- Stiff brush (1)

- Soft brush (1)
- Microfiber cloth (1)

- Hose (1)

- Stiff brush (1)

We can see that we have all the required tools for both tasks, but we need to allocate them efficiently.

Let's analyze the tasks and their dependencies:

Task A:
1. Clean the stained area with a mild soap solution and a soft-bristled brush to remove any loose debris. (Time: 5 minute(s)) (Tools: Soft brush)
2. Rinse the area thoroughly with water to remove any soap residue. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
3. Dry the area completely with a microfiber cloth. (Time: 3 minute(s)) (Tools: Microfiber cloth)
4. Apply a stain-removing product specifically designed for egg stains to the affected area. (Time: 1 minute(s)) (Tools: Sponge)
5. Let the product sit for the recommended amount of time, usually 10-15 minutes. (Time: 12 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
6. Rinse the area thoroughly with water to remove the product and the egg stain. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: None)
7. Dry the area completely with a microfiber cloth. (Time: 3 minute(s)) (Tools: Microfiber cloth)
8. Apply a coat of touch-up paint to the affected area that matches the car's original paint color. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Paintbrush)
9. Apply a clear coat of paint to seal and protect the area. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Paintbrush)
10. Buff the area with a polishing compound to blend the repair with the surrounding paint. (Time: 10 minute(s)) (Tools: Sponge)

Task B:
1. Rinse the wheels with water, focusing on the buildup around the spokes. (Time: 4 minute(s)) (Tools: Hose)
2. Spray each wheel with a non-acidic wheel cleaner. (Time: 2 minute(s)) (Tools: Hose, Spray bottle)
3. Use a soft-bristle brush to work the cleaner into a lather on the wheel surface. (Time: 5 minute(s)) (Tools: Hose, Spray bottle, Soft brush)
4. Scrub the wheel wells with a stiff-bristle brush and an all-purpose car cleaner. (Time: 8 minute(s)) (Tools: Stiff brush)
5. Rinse the wheels thoroughly with water. (Time: 3 minute(s)) (Tools: Hose)
6. Dry the wheels with a clean microfiber cloth. (Time: 6 minute(s)) (Tools: Microfiber cloth)

We can see that Task A requires the sponge for steps 4 and 10, and Task B requires the stiff brush for step 4.

Since we have only one sponge, we cannot complete both tasks concurrently. However, we can allocate the tools efficiently to minimize the total time.
